settings.text: If you think you may have cellulitis, erysipelas, or impetigo, see your doctor right away for proper diagnosis and treatment. Early treatment is important to prevent the infection from spreading and becoming more serious. In order to better understand skin infections, Welzo users should read this article.

settings.heading: How to Diagnose Cellulitis , Erysipelas and Impetigo

settings.text:
A bacterial skin infection called cellulitis can be challenging to identify. The most crucial thing to keep in mind is that cellulitis is a serious infection that requires prompt antibiotic treatment. Consult a doctor right away if you suspect you have cellulitis.

A type of superficial cellulitis that affects the top layers of the skin is erysipelas. It frequently manifests as an itchy, bright red rash that spreads quickly. Erysipelas is also brought on by bacteria, like cellulitis, and needs to be treated with antibiotics.

A less serious skin infection brought on by bacteria is impetigo. It typically affects children and is distinguished by skin sores or blisters. Generally speaking, impetigo is less severe than cellulitis or erysipelasy.

settings.heading: What are the causes of cellulitis, erysipelas, and impetigo?

settings.text:
Bacteria are to blame for impetigo, erysipelas, and cellulitis. Bacteria from the streptococcus or staphylococcus species are typically the cause of cellulitis and erysipelas. Staphylococcus bacteria typically cause impetigo.

When the skin is damaged, bacteria can enter and cause an infection. A cut, scrape, insect bite, or other wound may be the cause of this. If you have eczema or other skin conditions that lead to skin breaks, your risk of getting these infections is also increased.

settings.heading: Who is at risk for cellulitis, erysipelas, and impetigo?

settings.text:
Anyone can get impetigo, erysipelas, or cellulitis. However, some individuals are more vulnerable. These consist of:

-Diabetic patients and those with other circulatory disorders

-Those with compromised immune systems

-Those who have recently undergone surgery

-Patients who have spent a lot of time in the hospital

-Users of intravenous drugs

-Babies and children

settings.heading: How are cellulitis, erysipelas, and impetigo treated?

settings.text:
Antibiotics are used to treat impetigo, erysipelas, and cellulitis. Antibiotics administered orally or intravenously are typically needed to treat erysipelas and cellulitis. In many cases, over-the-counter antibiotics can be used to treat impetigo.

Even if you start to feel better, it's crucial to finish all of your antibiotics if you have cellulitis or erysipelas. This aids in limiting the spread of the infection.

Cellulitis, erysipelas, and impetigo complications

If left untreated, cellulitis, erysipelas, and impetigo can all result in serious complications. Cellulitis can spread to the bloodstream and lymph nodes, creating an infection that could be fatal. The lymph nodes and bloodstream are other places where erysipelas can spread. Secondary skin infections can result from impetigo.

settings.heading: When should I see a doctor?

settings.text:
If you suspect that you have impetigo, erysipelas, or cellulitis, visit your doctor right away. To avoid severe complications, these conditions need to be treated right away with antibiotics.

How can I avoid getting impetigo, erysipelas, and cellulitis?

By taking good care of your skin, you can help prevent cellulitis, erysipelas, and impetigo. This comprises:

-Maintaining dry, clean skin

-Utilizing sunscreen outside

-Putting on protective gear when outside

Avoiding contact with those who are infected by these diseases

-Promptly tending to cuts, scrapes, and other wounds

-Avoid sharing washcloths, towels, or other private items.

-If you have eczema, stick to your treatment schedule to maintain healthy skin.
